title: 109_hr2981
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. Congress finds that approximately 60 percent of Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives live on or near Indian lands with a high unemployment rate of 45 percent. These individuals own over 197,000 businesses, generating more than $34 billion in revenue. The service industry accounts for 17 percent of these businesses, followed by construction at 13.9 percent and retail trade at 7.5 percent. Business ownership among Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives grew by 84 percent from 1992 to 1997, with gross receipts increasing by 179 percent, outpacing the growth of all businesses during that period. The Small Business Development Center program is cost-effective, with clients generating additional tax revenues of $468,000,000 in 1998, six times the program's cost to the Federal Government. Business counseling and technical assistance are crucial on Indian lands where such services are scarce and expensive. Increased counseling through the program has been shown to reduce. The Act aims to stimulate economies, foster economic development, and assist in creating and expanding small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. It also provides management, technical, and research assistance to these businesses and seeks advice from Tribal Councils on where assistance is most needed. The goal is to ensure full access to business resources for Indian tribe members and Native populations. The Act aims to stimulate economies and assist in creating and expanding small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. It seeks advice from Tribal Councils on where small business development assistance is most needed and ensures full access to existing business counseling and technical assistance for these populations. Small Business Development Center assistance is provided to Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. The Small Business Act is amended to provide an additional grant for eligible states with a population of at least 1% Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians to assist with small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. The Small Business Act is amended to provide grants for states with a population of at least 1% Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians to support small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. Grant applicants must submit required information to the Administration. The Small Business Act is amended to provide grants for states with a population of at least 1% Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Grant applicants must comply with all requirements, except for matching funds, and can receive up to $300,000 in grants per fiscal year. Regulations will be established after consultation and comment. The Small Business Act is amended to provide grants for states with a population of at least 1% Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Grant recipients can receive over $300,000 per fiscal year. Final regulations will be issued to establish standards for educational, technical, and support services provided by Small Business Development Centers. The Administration may require a Small Business Development Center to develop definitions for Indian lands and Indian tribe as per specific legal references. The term 'Indian tribe' refers to any band, nation, or organized group of Indians in the contiguous United States, including the Metlakatla Indian Community. 'Indian tribe member' is a member of an Indian tribe, excluding Alaska Natives. 'Alaska Native' is defined as per the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. 'Native Hawaiian' refers to an individual meeting specific criteria. In section 3(b) of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act, the term 'Native Hawaiian' is defined as a descendant of the aboriginal people who occupied Hawaii before 1778. The term 'tribal organization' is defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. $7,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2008 for this purpose. Authorization of $7,000,000 for fiscal years 2006-2008 for Native Hawaiian programs, with funding limitations specified. The Small Business Act is amended to require Small Business Development Centers to seek advice from tribal organizations on how to assist Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians.
